unnormalised: So, someone asked about planning the perfect Indian wedding? It's a marathon, not a sprint, especially when you factor in auspicious timings. First, pandits usually look at birth charts to determine the shubh mahurat, that's the auspicious date and time. Dates like 14/01 (Makar Sankranti) or festivals can be good starting points, but you absolutely need the Pandit ji's approval. Plus, you'll need to consider availability of venues and vendors if you're planning around peak season like Oct-Nov (Diwali time).
normalised: So, someone asked about planning the perfect Indian wedding? It's a marathon, not a sprint, especially when you factor in auspicious timings. First, pandits usually look at birth charts to determine the shubh mahurat, that's the auspicious date and time. Dates like fourteenth January or festivals can be good starting points, but you absolutely need the Pandit ji's approval. Plus, you'll need to consider availability of venues and vendors if you're planning around peak season like October November (Diwali time).

unnormalised: Next, factor in all the pre-wedding rituals. Things like the Haldi, Mehendi, and Sangeet usually happen 1-3 days before the actual wedding date. If the shaadi is on, say, 20/12, you'll need to prep everything from 17/12 onwards. Also, remember to confirm timings with family members as some ceremonies can be very early, like 4:00 AM for certain poojas. Don’t forget travel time for out-of-town guests and to include buffer hours – Indians standard time is often +/- 2 hours from the actual schedule!
normalised: Next, factor in all the pre-wedding rituals. Things like the Haldi, Mehendi, and Sangeet usually happen one to three days before the actual wedding date. If the shaadi is on, say, twentieth December, you'll need to prep everything from seventeenth December onwards. Also, remember to confirm timings with family members as some ceremonies can be very early, like four zero zero A-M for certain poojas. Don't forget travel time for out-of-town guests and to include buffer hours – Indians standard time is often plus or minus two hours from the actual schedule!

unnormalised: Finally, prep for possible delays. It's an Indian wedding! Delays are practically a tradition. Buffer time is key. Also, communicate timelines clearly. If the baraat is supposed to arrive by 11:00 AM, make sure the family's aware that even 12:00 PM is still considered relatively on time! Use apps or shared spreadsheets to keep everyone informed and updated on the day itself. Best of luck!
